history.content: This is a simultaneous degree is definitely doable! It is hard to tell the workload without knowing more information. Maybe make an advising appointment once school starts to talk about strategies about how to go about doing this that is best for you.

I was a simultaneous major in Bioengineering and CS. For me, the workload was very heavy - I ended up staying an extra semester and took 2 summer sessions. I took 3 technical classes every semester. Deciding to go for the sim. degree really depends on what your goals are. Taking more classes means you will have less time for side projects, research, socializing, etc. You can be very clever with how you count your classes (for instance, while you are only allowed to double count 2 upper division classes, you can double count as many lower division classes as you like between the two degrees). I say only do the simultaneous degree if you absolutely want both degrees. For me, it was worth it since I felt no degree really met the requirements for what I wanted to do (computational biology). I would have done L&S CS if I was more interested in straight up software engineering and I would have stuck to Bioengineering alone if I didn't like programming so much. Also, keep in mind just how valuable a CS or EECS degree will be and consider the option of minoring in engineering. Anyways, best of luck and feel free to ask anything else about the process!

I was a simultaneous major in Bioengineering and CS. The workload is certainly very heavy - I ended up staying an extra semester and took 2 summer sessions. I took 3 technical classes every semester. Deciding to go for the sim. degree really depends on what your goals are. Taking more classes means you will have less time for side projects, research, socializing, etc. You can be very clever with how you count your classes (for instance, while you are only allowed to double count 2 upper division classes, you can double count as many lower division classes as you like between the two degrees). I say only do the simultaneous degree if you absolutely want both degrees. For me, it was worth it since I felt no degree really met the requirements for what I wanted to do (computational biology). I would have done L&S CS if I was more interested in straight up software engineering and I would have stuck to Bioengineering alone if I didn't like programming so much. Also, keep in mind just how valuable a CS or EECS degree will be! Anyways, best of luck and feel free to ask anything else about the process.

Has anyone done this before for a non-EECS engineering major with Computer Science in L&S? And how was the workload? My overall technical GPA might not be high enough to make the cut off to change my major to EECS but I have a high chance of meeting the 3.3 cap for L&S CS. Should I just go for the simultaneous major, or maybe even just switch out to L&S CS? Thanks in advance!

TL;DR in engineering but not EECS, really like CS but also like engineering courses and wondering if its a good idea to do a simultaneous major or switch out of CoE if I meet the 3.3 cap
history.subject: Simultaneous Major?
